p: Although HCV has been identified as a prominent agent of tubulointerstitial damage in a large series [ 4], glomerular diseases remain the most frequent kidney disease associated with HCV. The relationship between HCV and glomerular disease has been noted in both the native kidneys and after solid organ transplant (kidneys, liver, or liver/kidney transplant). In the past two decades, a consistent link has been noted between HCV and immune complex (IC) glomerular disease, including membranoproliferative and membranous glomerulonephritis [ 1, 2].
